content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Well then.  I feel like this will forever occupy the spot of "A game that no sane person could comprehend without playing" and anyone who tries to describe it will sound like either a madman, or the most boring man in existence.  Yes, it's a "Paperwork Simulator."  Or as Yahtzee put it best, a "Beurocracy 'em up."  And yet it genuinely is something worth trying.  I doubt it will enrapture everyone, it's definitely for the "Art Game" demographic - but it gets its point off well, and is a surprisingly engrossing thriller of sorts and there's a weird charm and atmosphere that takes you in, and while its still best played in short bursts - it doesn't get as repetitive as it might seem either.  It's not going to appeal to everyone, but if you want to try something that just might surprise you - this is a good offering at a nice price.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Papers, Please is definitely an addicting game. It has 20 different endings, so there is replay value. Your first playthrough will really be entirely getting used to the system and to be as quick and efficient as possible, in order to maximize how much money you make everyday. Additionally, as a Passport Control Officer, you have to make decisions which will affect your character's, and your family's lives. Whether helping take down the government by letting terrorists through, letting people take vigiliante justice, denying people entry even though they may be executed if they return to their home country, or personally killing people to provide for your family. This is not "Passport Control Simulator." In this game, you really have to pay attention, and it is good for your brain, because you have to juggle multiple documents at the same time and remember dates and so forth off the top of your head on the fly. Not only that, it realy makes you question what you would do in these circumstances; help others at your family's expense, or only look out for yourself. Though it will get dull rather quickly, it is definitely worth the few bucks it costs.

												HIGHLY recommend this game. Essentially, in this game you play as a border agent who has to examine passports and other official documentation to determine whether a person is allowed entry into your country or not. The game starts off relatively easy and slowly progresses into a more complicated game as you progress. If you mess up, you'll be deducted pay at the end of the work day and your family will undoubtedly suffer as a result. While it sounds rather tedious and repetitive, it does suck you in. Before you know, you've wasted 6 hours trying to provide for your family while watching out for illegals.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Once again, another staggeringly unique title is pulled out of the seemingly endless hat of indie game concepts. This time in the form of a disturbingly farmiliar dystopian society known as Arstotzka. While it may seem like the monotonous, dull drone of endlessly stamping passports; Papers, Please is a game of moral conflict. In the world of Papers, Please, you play as an unnamed protagonist, a mid level beaurocrat, working in a border checkpoint that seems like a parallel to East and West Berlin in the 80s. We can only assume these countries are roughly based on the Soviet Union or other Soviet influenced republics. The graphic style has an appropriately grey and muddled appearance that fits the situation very well. The gameplay is deliberately dull, which may be difficult for some to appreciate. As you go down the line, you begin to work in a rhythm. As you gain this rhythm you have satisfaction for catching frauds and it becomes fun in a droning, dull way. Later into the game you may look up, horrified, and realized that you have become a cog in the machine. You have begun processing people and are shocked with how you can dehumanize them in such a way. Sometimes you want to help others, but your family is still barely hovering above the poverty line. How can you keep them alive without accepting bribes or perhaps sending a poor traveller back to their home country where they will die because they do not have the correct papers? That is the beauty of Papers, Please or better yet, that is what is ugly and disgusting about Papers, Please; but we love it so.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												A fantastic game from 2013. I wasn't able to play it until i had the urge to use steam as i am primarily a PS3 player, but i watched a bunch of youtube videos of people who played it and it looked great then. While it may look bland upon first glance; you are a border inspector checking passports and documents to decide who enters and who leaves and it isn't the best job to have in real life. In the game however this job becomes interesting as you encounter various characters that can affect you and events that you can choose or choose not to take part in. All of which change the course the story takes.I like how the game presents choice in the game. It isn't in your face about whether or not you should or shouldn't take part in the situations you come across and whether or not it is good or bad like the decisions in many bioware games. So if your roleplaying as yourself in the game you make the decisions you think are right. Or you can roleplay as something else and do what the character you are roleplaying would do. The atmosphere and asthetics feel right. The simple graphics give it an old time feeling that go well with the setting in the game. The main theme and sounds throughout the game are unique.The only bad thing i can really see about the game is that it may get repetitive on multiple playthroughs in the story mode as many events take place on the same day everytime. Although you can set yourself some challenges to spice it up a bit like a no mistakes playthrough. You may notice the same npc's in the same playthrough as well. Although you can set yourself some challenges to spice it up a bit like a no mistakes playthrough. The game has an endless mode as well so events are randomized and there are other game types in there.Overall it is a fantastic game to playthrough at least once just for the experience. It may not be appealing to some people but give it a shot.Glory to Arstotska! And Jorji!

Posted: August 27, 2014
												I work in security, and do this job on a daily basis, and even I find it difficult to scan through documents fast enough to turn a profit in this game. Perhaps I'm just in the habit of being too thorough, having been trained to check, double-check, and cross-reference every piece of information I collect.That said, this is an otherwise excellent execution of concept, and does a good job of putting the player in a difficult spot. Very few games are going to make you choose between feeding your starving children and risking a prison sentence, and even fewer are going to succeed at making it fun.

												"Why not to take a trip to pass-dystopian 80s, and see all the might of Eastern Europe autocracys? Let's face together those lousy travellers and immigrants, as they wish to entry trough our strict borders. Get your documents ready, citizens! Check your passports, inhabitants! Make sure you have proper entry permits, foreigners! Or should we perhamps support our local conspiracy theoretics and shoot some arrogant ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, before they cross the line? We might also need to accept some of those bribe offers we're encountering to feed our starving families. Oh boy, my dear son's birthday is tomorrow, need to get a gift for him! But then we won't be able to buy any essential food or medicines tomorrow..." The atmosphere of this game is over the edge. All of your acts have consequences, everything is connected and nothing is guaranteened. After all, this might be one of the best indie-releases in the short run. Oh, and one more thing, before entering. "Papers, please?"

content:
Posted: August 12, 2013
												For one month in late 1982, you are an immigration officer who must allow those with valid passports to enter, and turn away anyone with conflicting, outdated, or falsified credentials.  Easy at first, but something new gets added to the mix each day during the intensifying conflict, paranoia, and border tension between two countries.  Do well enough, and you might just make enough money for you and your ailing family to survive the winter...but time is short, mistakes are costly, and increasingly harrowing dilemmas will present themselves.  You will likely learn something new about yourself if you make it all the way through, and it won't be a pleasant revelation.You should play it, it's awesome.GLORY TO ARSTOTSKA

Posted: May 21, 2015
												Very polite title, which I appreciate. Most other games are so aggressively named, but Papers Please has the decency to ask nicely. Especially good given the nature of the game and its depiction of a totalitarian police state with strict and unwavering border control regulations. Juxtaposition is a great word to play in Scrabble if you can get your hands on an X or a Blank. Just wait until somebody writes "position" and then add the "juxta" with the biggest look of smugness you can muster. That's my favourite part of Scrabble. My favourite part of this game though is the achievement you can get for being arrested for being too honest. That made me happy.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												I didn't buy this last time I'd seen it on sale, but it had certainly peaked my interest. I bought it this time and I'm glad I did!I wasn't really expecting much of this game, but it ended up being splendid - simple yet wonderful. You have a choice no matter the situation and you have up to twenty endings you could end up with (reminds me of those stories when I was a child with the multiple endings, can't remember what they're called). Most of the endings seem to require different sacrifices you have to make along the way and give a realistic insight to the life of a border officer. It explores not only moral issues but corruption, blackmail, terrorism, bribery, etc. which is honestly a good portrayal of today's society. Following the rules to a T or being honest will not give you a good ending. As each day moves forward, you are introduced to new daily tasks, many of which might be unfair to the person crossing the border. You get plenty of different people - some who are obviously crooks and some who just want to be free of their old country or visit a family member. There's a secret organization trying to infiltrate your country as well and whether you decide to help them or not, the consequences might never be the same. I don't know. It's entertaining and makes you ask questions. I think that makes this game a very good one, despite how repetitive it is. You're at least engaged with the central story and your life, your family's lives, and countless other families' lives depend on your decision, whereas other games like this might not make you have such conscious choices where so much relies on said choices, which really makes Papers, Please stand out.Definitely recommended. (:

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
Papers, Please manages to make what would seem like a midless task mean lots to the player, all while presenting new challenges and thrills throughout the game and managing to be terrifyingly immersive. This is the only game where poor controls can be described as intentional, and they are, to make the grinding task of passport-stamping intentionally tedious and frustrating. Even as a humble worker, you feel powerful as you stamp the papers of endless npcs, some of which contribute to the story. While it won't appeal to those gamers who want nothing but the finest gameplay, the aesthetic, story, message and overall tone of Papers, Please draws many to enjoy it. In fact, the strenuous task of paperwork shuffling can actually become fun and addicting to perfectionists like myself.While short, there are 20 endings in the game, 3 of which are considered "good". Obtaining my desired good ending is one of the most rewarding thigs I've experienced from a game.10 dollars is a bit of a stretch for those who don't know what they're getting from this game, but I would reccomend it to absolutely anyone on sale.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												This is a very interesting game. The depressive world and story mixed with that intense music, a game i've never played before. It's very difficult and challenging, it requires all your concentration to not miss a tiny detail on any of the given papers; this game is for open-minded people who like very challenging, brain straining games. I really enjoyed the flow of the game, and loved the story changing characters, which appear ever so often, as well as all the other little details put in it. While intensly working on checking data from the papers, you always have to be ready for a terrorist attack or some other event which may come unexpected. I also especially like the moral choices (which do not have influence on the story), for example, will you accept the wife to get to her husband even though she doesnt't have correct data? Will you accept bribes for people with not enough money to get the needed papers? Then there are bigger decisions that may change the complete story of the game, which I will not give an example for, because they might contain big spoilers. This game is definitely worth checking out, if you don't want to buy it, you might as well check out some videos on the web.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												Papers, Please is a punishing puzzle with an inventive story, told in a unique manner.Hopefully that didn't scare you off. It's clear that this is an indie game; most big publishers would be scared off by the game's punishing yet fundamentally repetitive gameplay. However, anyone who enjoys brainteasers and an excellent story will be impressed with Papers, Please.The game, which takes place in an Arstotzkan border checkpoint at East Grestin, is based on sorting through papers. Does this person have all required papers? Are the papers valid? Does anything about the documents conflict with something else? These, and other new complexities, are difficult to understand at a glance, so game difficulty is no problem (though I haven't tried the Easy Mode yet). New twists, often caused by events at your own checkpoint (Kolechians are temporarily forbidden from entering Arstotzka following a Kolechian terrorist attack), are introduced, and often moral dilemmas arise, as bribes, anti-government rebel agents, and star-crossed lovers (Ooh-la-la) are frequent occurences on this border. Money troubles also appear, as you must maintain your family of four (fun things like "Your wife, uncle, and son died" are treated with little fanfare).The depth of the story (which has 20 endings) is (quite) deep. The unique method of storytelling, where you see just a snapshot of the lives of travelers, is enough to recommend the game on. The gameplay is interesting, but loses much of its appeal early on. For one to look at this as an incredibly difficult and intense virtual novel would be a good summary, and if you enjoy those types of things, then this could be one of your favorite new indie titles. For gameplay first, story second players, the game is likely to bore you, as the story is the real selling point here.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Papers, Please is a game about the morality of beaurocracy. It's not necessarily fun; in fact, I think it's generally experienced as either mundanely boring or extremely stressful, but it's extraordinarily rewarding. You play as a border checkpoint inspector overseeing the entry of immigrants, returnees, and visitors into a fictionalized analogue of East Berlin under the Soviet Bloc, and the game follows your everyday life in your job over the course of one month. You have a family to feed and the political situation is worsening. On the first day, your job is easy: the checkpoint has just opened, so you only have to let citizens back into the country and keep everyone else out. The next day, the restrictions loosen and foreigners can be let in if they have the correct documentation. Soon terrorist attacks stop your days short and the security requirements tighten. From there, things get complicated.There's basically two parts to this game: you have to figure out what you're "supposed to" do and what the correct protocol is, and then you have to decide whether or not you should do it. Rigidly following the system of often sexist, transphobic, racist, classist, or just generally heartless beaurocratic policy will leave you facing the human results of those actions, but be too kind and your family will starve or you might be sent to prison. There's 20 different endings reflecting the variety of ways in which your actions can influence the game world, a standard RPG feature these days, but perhaps uniquely all of the most powerful moments in the game come on the way to those endings and not in them. It's a hugely moving and interesting experience, and the utilitarian faux-Soviet aesthetic of the thing never breaks for a second. One of my favourite games of all time.Glory to Arstotzka. Cause no trouble, friend.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Well then.  I feel like this will forever occupy the spot of "A game that no sane person could comprehend without playing" and anyone who tries to describe it will sound like either a madman, or the most boring man in existence.  Yes, it's a "Paperwork Simulator."  Or as Yahtzee put it best, a "Beurocracy 'em up."  And yet it genuinely is something worth trying.  I doubt it will enrapture everyone, it's definitely for the "Art Game" demographic - but it gets its point off well, and is a surprisingly engrossing thriller of sorts and there's a weird charm and atmosphere that takes you in, and while its still best played in short bursts - it doesn't get as repetitive as it might seem either.  It's not going to appeal to everyone, but if you want to try something that just might surprise you - this is a good offering at a nice price.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Papers, Please has to rank up there as one of my favorite gaming experiences of the year. You take on the role of border passport inspector for an impoverished East German-esque dystopia. Your job is to check each applicant's paperwork, verify their authenticity, and either approve or deny them entry. The graphics and gameplay are incredibly drab and monotonous, yet there are many well developed underlying story arcs, truly difficult moral choices, and an ever present sense of oppression that gives this game a unique and amazing feel all its own, and makes it hard to walk away from until you see it through to one of its many (usually grim, or at best, bittersweet) endings.This is a tough game to describe and sell to friends, because at its core, it's a paper-pushing bureaucracy simulator with pixelated graphics and a depressing mood, but it is so, so much more than that (trust me!). If you like games, or you even like a really interesting (and not too time consuming) experience, you owe it to pick up this jem for its bargain bin price.Glory to Arstotzka!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												Who would have thought that doing something as boring as managing a border would be so fun? Honestly, I didn't think there was any way it could have been entertaining. Oh boy was I proven wrong real quick. It's micro-managment, loophole searching and timed frenzy gameplay all at once. Do you try and rush through to get more people through in a day and risk missing something? Or perhaps take your time and make sure your making the right choice letting this person through? Or just through all of the rules out of the window and let someone pass because they give you a story about their family waiting for them on the other side of the checkpoint and make your own sob story worse? And speaking of story, it has to be one of the best game narritives in recent past with all of the people interactions and ending you can get. All in all, don't judge this game based on what it looks like because it is so much better than that. It's fantastic.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Many games and companies claim to be inovated or trying to push the norm and being progressive. In the past Nintendo were the biggest innovators pushing the gaming industry with new ideas on how to play video games. The past few years the gaming industry has seen little to almost no new ideas since the wii came to store shelves. All of this is important because you won't see innovation from some big company; you will find it from some indie developer called Lucas Pope. A man who used to work for Naughty Dog Studios working on the beaten to death series Uncharted broke free and decided to do his own thing.    This game just surprised me from every aspect and I just wanted more and more. The gameplay consist of reading things carefully and making sure everything matches to what it is supposed to be. If things don't match or seem fishy you will deny or detain a person. Sounds easy at first but you must do all this under a strict clock. You get money for every person you deny or pass, but you do thing wrong and you get fined for it. And you need this money to pay rent, feed your family, keep them warm, and healthy. You can barely get enough money to do all of these things for your family. You need to manage your money very carefully.     This game is maybe one of the best games I played in my life. It is so different and original and it does it all in such a fantastic way. I highly reccomend everyone to play this game if you ever get the chance. I only wish more games to take such new approaches to gameplay can come out sooner.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												This is one of the most unique games to come around in many years.  A cold war based theme set in 1982 where you decide on the entrance of people into your country, the "Glorious" Arstotzka.  The game difficulty starts slowly as you check the validity of people's documents at the border. This continues to build as more complex events occur adding more and more information to verify and new methods to test the stories of the masses.  At the end of the work day, you are paid by how many people you processed and penalized for mistakes made.  Your money is used to support your family, providing as good a living as you can for the necessities of life: Rent, food, heat, medicine.  It is a serious challege to process as many as you can while not letting criminals, terrorists, and other "undesirables" into your country.A word about the graphics:  they are intentionally low end to give the feel for what games were back in the 80's.  Nevertheless, what gamers often times fail to remember, it is the imagination that is the most important piece of play.  Many of you will recall how the BEST and most fun you had as a kid was when you had a tree branch sword, a pine cone grenade, or a fort made of boxes.  This frame of mind is nearly lost on the current generation as graphics have all but stunted their ability to dream and pretend.  This game deserves a look for the price, currently $5.  Those of you who remember the cold war era will laugh at the feel of the game, while those who do not may find that they actually have a great time with it as they strengthen "the muscle of their imagination" that has been dormant for perhaps their whole lives.  Glory to Arstotzka!

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												When I first turned on Papers, Please...I wasn't sure what to expect, I hadn't watched any videos about the game or even read very much about it. It was a Humble Bundle pack-in and I thought it might be interesting.I was absolutely right. Papers, Please is easily one of my top games of ALL TIME. The gameplay begins as simple, but gradually becomes more and more challenging as the game carries forward. Small subplots twist and turn the otherwise very straightforward storyline...There is a good chunk of comedy relief as well (Lolibutts loves you Jorgi), and a little heartstring pulling here and there. There are also 20 different endings. Which is pretty damn cool if you ask me. Overall, I'd say give this game a try if you're in the mood to try something "Different". It can get frustrating at times when the slightest detail was overlooked and costs you credits or just ups your citation count...but luckily you can always replay the day later. Addicting, fun, and just plain original. Glory to Astolska. 9/10

However, you are not the only one you are looking out for: A man makes it through the checkpoint, and his wife follows, but does not have the proper paperwork. Do you let her through, accepting the consiquences, or do you destroy a family? Do you assist the mysterious group claiming to try to overthrow the corrupt government? Do you allow a potential terrorist through, if his bribe is good enough to buy medicine for your son? All of this geniously squeesed into a simple choice: Approved or denied.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												'Papers, Please' is not easy to describe. It isn't what most people would consider a traditional game. There are no points, and winning or losing isn't as black-and-white as you may be used to. You could categorize it as a bureaucracy simulator or an everyday survival game, and that wouldn't necessarily be wrong, but it would definitely miss the point. 'Papers, Please' is — at its heart — an adventure game.Though everything takes place from within a tiny border checkpoint, the game's drama and tension all comes from the decisions you're forced to make. You'll never feel more anxious stamping a piece of virtual paper than you will when playing this game. You will legitimately hate your supervisor, and you might even care about the people who pass through your little booth.TL;DR: Get this game if you're looking for insightful, clever political commentary.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												A friend of mine once remarked that there's no way to describe this game that still makes it sound fun once you've explained it. By all reason, Papers Please shouldn't be as much of a good time as it is. You serve as an unnamed male citizen of the Arstozkan Empire, employed by lottery to rigorously scan and verify documents at the newest border crossing station in your dystopian, communist nation circa the 1980s. The names are all changed, but you essentially control Checkpoint Charlie at the Berlin Wall, and it's your job to make sure illegal immigration in your sector grinds to a halt. If you fail, your impoverished family will starve and freeze even worse than they already do.But in spite of all its Cold War doom and gloom, Papers Please is a wonderfully intricate and engaging experience. The charm and humor of its characters, such as the permanently cheerful Jorgi Costava or the irascible Dimitri (Your supervisor, who stops by to inform you how bad you're doing each week) draws you in with each passport you process. Soon, you're reading your employee handbook to pass the time, determined to serve your country well and provide for your family. Or maybe you begin working undercover with the resistance, smuggling revolutionaries into the country with falsified papers. Or maybe you set up a smuggling business with a few regular border-crossers, and plan to flee the country yourself. With 20 different endings to unlock and hundreds of stories to hear, Papers Please is unique kind of game; one that defies the genres of the medium and forces us to think differently about our entertainment. I highly recommend you pick it up. And remember! Always read the daily bulletin!Glory to Arstotzka!

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Set in a dystopian world. You have "won" a job at your country's border. You stamp passports, granting or denying entry to people trying to get into Arstotzka.Sounds dull? Well, it's actually incredibly addictive. This game is innovative and surprisingly fun--albeit rather grim. The game is presented as a story that takes place over 31 playable days (there is also a endless mode that can be unlocked). As the story progresses, stamping passports becomes more and more complicated and there will be moral choices you must make. There's even a fair amount of replayability, as you can get different endings depending on what choices you make throughout the game.The only thing I found irritating was how incredibly nitpicky the game can be sometimes. But it's still very fun and very addictive.Highly recommended if you want to experience a game that is different.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												A fantastic game from 2013. I wasn't able to play it until i had the urge to use steam as i am primarily a PS3 player, but i watched a bunch of youtube videos of people who played it and it looked great then. While it may look bland upon first glance; you are a border inspector checking passports and documents to decide who enters and who leaves and it isn't the best job to have in real life. In the game however this job becomes interesting as you encounter various characters that can affect you and events that you can choose or choose not to take part in. All of which change the course the story takes.I like how the game presents choice in the game. It isn't in your face about whether or not you should or shouldn't take part in the situations you come across and whether or not it is good or bad like the decisions in many bioware games. So if your roleplaying as yourself in the game you make the decisions you think are right. Or you can roleplay as something else and do what the character you are roleplaying would do. The atmosphere and asthetics feel right. The simple graphics give it an old time feeling that go well with the setting in the game. The main theme and sounds throughout the game are unique.The only bad thing i can really see about the game is that it may get repetitive on multiple playthroughs in the story mode as many events take place on the same day everytime. Although you can set yourself some challenges to spice it up a bit like a no mistakes playthrough. You may notice the same npc's in the same playthrough as well. Although you can set yourself some challenges to spice it up a bit like a no mistakes playthrough. The game has an endless mode as well so events are randomized and there are other game types in there.Overall it is a fantastic game to playthrough at least once just for the experience. It may not be appealing to some people but give it a shot.Glory to Arstotska! And Jorji!

content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												Frankly, this game is masterfully done. The idea is original, the graphics fit the claustrophobic and choking atmosphere, the music enhances the idea of a smothering government regime in which the player finds himself as both citizen and employee, and the stories told through the window of your booth are engaging and develop themselves with intrigue and secrecy. It's hard to find where this game could be improved. It's something that works so well as a game, and as an educational experience that it could almost be used in a teaching environment. The idea that a citizen of this government would be placed into the position they are, allowing or denying various people access to their country, seeing the amount of paperwork involved, watching the rules and regulations pile up and change over the course of time leading to frustration, being faced with the moral dilemmas asked of them, and deciding how to handle their allegiance to country versus their conscious and compassion for other human beings is something that truly isn't captured as well as it is here with Papers, Please. I will say that the game is so well done, that it actually feels like work after awhile, which cuts into the fun factor, though it enchances the simulation aspect. It's almost hard to qualify it into a genre. The mechanics are crisp and clean, they build on themselves day after day, slowly increasing the difficulty by usually adding one or two additional rules, and eventually the player will find that they are totally immersed in the experience. It does feel like work after awhile though, so some players may actually be glad to 'punch out' after an hour or two of game play.This is a game that has  left me thinking about it long after I exit the program. It's something that reaches a state where it's actually more than a game, it's a slice of actual human life. This falls into the same category as This War of Mine in that it's an important game, and one that people should play with more in mind that just entertainment. Excellent, excellent purchase.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
Quick Breakdown: A stellar game where you play as an inspector working at a border checkpoint between your communist country of Arstotzka, and the neighboring country Kolechia, which your country has just recently ended a 6 year war with.Length: 2-4 hours (Main game), 8-10 (Completionists)Score: 8.5/10Full Review: Papers Please is a truly unique game. Admittedly, it’s a pretty tough sell. On paper, the game sounds like it’d be awful. Even when I purchased the game, I wasn’t really sold on it, but I took a chance on it based on the ravings from my friends, and the low sale price of $2.50. After playing the game, I’m glad I did. It’s worth getting at full price even, but this is Steam, we all wait for the sales, don’t we?So why’s it a tough sell? Well, you play as an inspector at a border checkpoint. People give you their papers needed to enter, and you look over them and either let them enter your country,  deny them entry if their papers are not all in order, or even detain them if need be. Sound like fun? To me it didn’t, but maybe you can see the appeal there.So why is it worth playing? Odd as it may be, that very task I talked about in the last paragraph actually is a lot of fun. But there’s further reason that is even more compelling. You work for the glorious country or Arstotzka, at the checkpoint the border town of Grestin. The half of Grestin belongs to the neighboring country of Kolechia, which Arstotzka has just ended a 6 year war with. Your border checkpoint has just opened because of this, and people are once again allowed to enter Arstotzka for the first time in 6 years. This setting, and the people it brings through your checkpoint, and the events it leads to, are the game’s biggest strengths. You’ll encounter natives trying to re-enter the country, foreigners who can finally come to Arstotzka to work or visit, or even just pass through. There will also be terrorists, who aim to harm your glorious country, and it is your duty to deny and even detain them.The game’s story and dialogue are both well written. Your actions during the day (the gameplay portion, which we’ll get to in a moment) affect the story between days, and down the road. Both the one time characters passing through, and those who are recurring are interesting, and some even quite memorable. (I think everyone who’s played this game loves Jorji). The dialogue is quite good, and has plenty of memorable lines.So what of the gameplay? It’s done in a single screen, divided into 3 portions. Roughly the top third of the screen is a top down view of the border checkpoint, the line, and the guards. This part isn’t used too often for gameplay. The bottom two thirds of the screen are divided as well, the left third presents a first person point of view from your place inside your border checkpoint. This is where applicants seeking entry to Arstotzka come in and give you your papers. The rest of the bottom portion of your screen is where you can look at said papers up close.Now this is the part of the game that I think is the hardest part to sell someone on, but I’m going to try anyway. When the game starts, applicants give you a passport, and so long as they are a resident of Arstotzka with a valid passport, they may enter the country. You simply stamp all passports with either “approved” or “denied.”At the end of the day you will be paid 5 credits for every person you correctly processed. The first two incorrectly processed applicants will earn you a citation with a warning and no payment, each error after that will also incur a penalty docking some of your pay. Citations are reset at the beginning of each day.During this end of day phase you will also need to balance your finances, and decide if you have money to pay for heat in your apartment, or to purchase food for your family. If you’re not able to take care of them properly they can die. If they’re all dead, or if you run out of money entirely you’ll get a gamer over (there are other ways to get a game over, in total the game has 20 different endings). So it’s important to do your job well.On day 2 things become more complicated, and foreigners may enter as well so long as their passport is valid. On each passport you have various things to check for, a valid issuing city, that their photo matches their physical appearance, and that it hasn’t yet expired.As the days go on more documents and rules will be introduced. I won’t go over all of them, but you will also have documents for entry permits, work permits, and you’ll need to crosscheck the name and passport number -as well as other information- on these documents with what’s printed on their passport. Sometimes you’ll also need to fingerprint an applicant, or search them for weapons or contraband (can’t let the drug smugglers and terrorists in). You’ll need to go over the documents carefully, pointing out discrepancies, and even giving a proper reason for denial. On occasion you’ll need to detain some of the applicants instead of simply denying them entry.That about covers the basics of the game, so let’s move on to the graphics. They’re done in a simple pixel style, they’re not anything fancy, but they are pleasant to look at, and they help set the dreary mood of the game.And it is quite dreary working this sort of job in an oppressive country, barely making enough to care for your family and survive. The music is good, and helps compliments this mood, and so do the sound effects.My main criticism of the game is levelled at trying to point out discrepancies. Now, it’s not that I have issue doing this, I enjoy it. No no, my issue is that while you know which rule is broken, it’s not always clear how to properly point this out. Once you do figure it out, it’s a non-issue the next time you must deny someone entry for the same reason, and it’s not an issue most of the time, but it happens occasionally, and there’s not really a good reason for it.In the end though, Papers Please is a fantastic game. If you’ve not played it yet, hopefully I’ve been able to convince you to give it a go, if you’re on the fence though, I urge you to gamble on it anyway, wait for a sale even if you wish. Just make sure that you do play this game.Glory to Arstotzka!

content:
Posted: September 13, 2013
												On paper, (no pun intended), this game has a pretty boring premise. See how much mind-numbing paperwork you can process in a day to make ends meet. It sounds like a level of enjoyment that can be achieved through the use of Microsft Excel. However, clever storytelling, surprising character development and a difficulty curve that increases as the layers of beaurocracy stack up, make this game intriguing and surprisingly addictive.It is 1982 in a fictional slice of Eastern Europe. The player becomes a border control inspector in the nightmare totalitarian state of Arstotzka, turning away impoverish families into the cold because their visas are a few weeks out of date. Or maybe you want to play the good guy and let a few desperate people slip through the net? But you also have a family to feed, and in this communist society, your salary is paid based on how many people you process correctly in a day. Too many citations and you’ll be the one left out in the cold.The simplistic graphics of this game are more than just nostalgia. They add to the impact when something shocking and unexpected happens. Like that guy with shifty-looking eyes strutting out of the ticket booth and shouting ‘GLORY TO KOLECHIA’, shortly before blowing himself up and redecorating the wall with the innards of your security guards.Your moral choices can alter the stormy political atmosphere, re-unite friends and lovers and deliver justice in any way you see fit. For people don't just live in the country. They ARE the country. I think my only complaint about the game is that it feels dry, sinister and clinical. I know that it was designed to be this way, but it means I can't play for any more than a few minutes before I just feel ... dirty inside ... and want to play something brighter, more colourful and happy.Nevertheless, Papers Please gets 9/10 from me. Glory to Arstotzka, komrade.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Lucas Pope's Paper's Please is an oddity, in that it's a "Dystopian Document Thriller". Reminiscent of Orwell's 1984, Papers Please takes place in Arstotzka, a fictional country that resembles an Eastern European country during the Cold War. Here in Arstotzka, you are a border checkpoint officer, looking over the passports and documents of all citizens attempting to cross into glorious Arstotzka, making sure they have all proper paperwork, whilst also making sure you family doesnt starve to death or get sick.Whilst this seems like it would make for a boring game, Papers Please is probably one of the tensest games i've played. It riddles you with moral choices, decisions that affect your future (and that of your family), and the stress of taking care of 5/6 individuals, being paid based on your performance. You have to decide if you are going to let you're family go hungry so that you can help you co-workers, or maybe not have any heating, in exchange for letting in one too many people whose stories touched you. Maybe you'll find yourself aiding a terrorist organisation, or even a vengeful father. Or perhaps you will stay a hardworking, productive member of Arstotzka, with all which that entails.Papers Please is an excellent game, with unique gameplay, hard moral decisions, a large amount of replayability and a fantastic audiovisual aesthetic. It is truly unique, and definitely a game that everyone needs to play. Glory to Arstotzka!

												First, I love the choice of graphics for Papers, Please. It captures what I remember from old point-and-click games. The overall feel is cold and oppressing, and the art supports that.On the surface, the gameplay is checking papers. The fun I had came from outcomes of how I dealt with residents, bribes, and assassination.What makes this game interesting is the morally gray area. You have to decide right from wrong, and it can be tough.The game is short, though it has 20 endings.I recommend Papers, Please because I haven't felt this game's vibe from any other game. The emotions are oppression to a degree, the pressure of decision making, and sometimes, tough luck.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												When I first heard about this game late last year, I thought "how on Earth can such a game be fun?" Now that I've finally played for some hours, I have to admit my first reaction to the game idea couldn't have been much farther from the mark. The background story is quite grim, having been influenced by the not so distant history, and this brings unforeseen depth to the game. However, humor is present as well, in the myriad funny details, cultural references, and indeed, the somewhat sparse unique characters. Even the cumbersome old smuggler who kept wasting my valuable inspector-time made me smile every time he trotted in front of the desk and started rambling cheerfully. The mechanic is quite ingenious in that it forces the player to make difficult choices: for instance, is it better to buy the essential supplies that are needed for the family to survive, or upgrades to the inspector's gear that, in the long run, enable the player to gain more money with which to secure their family's well-being? Choices that at first seem good investments in the future may turn out to be little more than shortcuts to an early grave, since a certain amount of randomness in the game's events ensures that each decision the player makes is laden with uncertainty. The carefully balanced mix of random and scripted events effectively create an addictive feeling that the player's actions have real consequences for the player's character and other characters as well. Well done.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												You have to buy this game, there's no option about it, if you have the money just buy it right now!This game forces you into a situation where you have to do your job near-perfectly to get enough money for your family to survive and be happy, but that involves screwing over a lot of helpless people in situations similar to yours! Will you work hard, not questioning the authorities and provide for your family; or do you make a sacrifice to help the common folk? That's up to you! A lot of other things go on, but I'll leave you to discover that because it's pretty mind blowing on your first play through! (As the game says, it's a Thriller)The gameplay is also surprisingly fun for a game about checking over paperwork, it involves a lot of thought and skill! It is extremely unique and it constantly throws new rules onto your job based on the events that happen in the game world, changing up the gameplay and making it more interesting day by day! The game also has a lot of replay value, with many different endings you can achieve and lots of different ways the story can drive forward based on your choices each day. You can replay any day or start a completely new game at any time without losing the progress of later days, so they give you full freedom to experiment and retry when things don't go how you wanted them to! You see all these people saying that video games can't be an art form, and this game can't be further from the truth. After playing this, no one could deny that video games are an art form. Just buy it now because you'll love it and you need to support true innovative and artistic games. BUY IT! I'm waiting...Bought it yet? No? Why the f*** not!?

												This is the mosty addictively boring game in the world. It's billed as a "dystopian document thriller", and I can say it certainly lives up the title. You're a border inspector for the Great Nation of Arstotzka, and all you will do all day is check the papers of travelers who are seeking entry into the country. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												This is the kind of indie game that I really like... it's obviously low-budget, and the graphics, interface and sound are totally old school. Yet, it doesn't matter, as the game itself is pretty unique and interesting... maybe even addictive.Basically, it's an exercise in concentration. Each day, your job as a passport-controller becomes more difficult. At first, there are like 2-3 things to watch out for. Each day, a new thing to observe and look out for is added, and so you need to remember more and more things to watch out for. Some of them don't come up for quite some time, but once you get too careless, you miss those things and fail. Fortunately, you can mess up a few times each day without having to pay a fee from your measly pay. Then again, the more complaints you get, the worse it gets, as there also is some kind of inspector who will judge your efficiency every once in a while. I recommend to write down the issueing cities from each region on a piece of paper... otherwise, you might lose quite some time checking every time. I have played this for 5 hours so far, in two sessions, and I notice that it really can eat away at your ability to concentrate, so I think this is best played casually... do like half an hour at a time so you don't burn yourself out.I really like the theme, as it DOES make you think a bit about how unfair the system in that country is, and you have to make some harsh decisions. There even are a few puzzles in there in the story-mode. Kudos to the developer... this is a fun little game, and to me, the old school graphics don't matter at all, as the core of the game is very well thought out, and it's fun!

												I wasn't really interested in this game when I bought it, nor did I really have a good idea of what it was.  My friend had said it was good, and it was on super sale.  Anyway...I wouldn't have thought that I would enjoy a game in which the main portion was scrutinizing papers, and looking for falsified documents, but I would have been wrong.  This game is loads of fun.It's unlike any game I have ever played for sure.  It's all about attention to detail, and you notice more and more as you play.  I feel like the skills I've earned in this game could even serve me in the real world.  You will learn to quickly scan and cross-check information for discrepancies. Everyday, more complications are added in various intriguing forms.The lives of your family depend on your performance at work, and it creates a sense of urgency.  The more people you process, the better you can take care of your family, but rush through it and you will start missing some of the most obvious mistakes.I'd go on, but I've hardly scratched the surface of this game.  If you think you have an eye for detail, and would like to put it to the test, then this is the game for you.  If not, try it anyway, because, like me, you might be surprised.  Feed your family.

												Papers, Please is an incredible game. It happens to be one of my favourites on Steam. The gameplay is always fun and engaging and is also rather addictive. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												This is the kind of indie game that I really like... it's obviously low-budget, and the graphics, interface and sound are totally old school. Yet, it doesn't matter, as the game itself is pretty unique and interesting... maybe even addictive.Basically, it's an exercise in concentration. Each day, your job as a passport-controller becomes more difficult. At first, there are like 2-3 things to watch out for. Each day, a new thing to observe and look out for is added, and so you need to remember more and more things to watch out for. Some of them don't come up for quite some time, but once you get too careless, you miss those things and fail. Fortunately, you can mess up a few times each day without having to pay a fee from your measly pay. Then again, the more complaints you get, the worse it gets, as there also is some kind of inspector who will judge your efficiency every once in a while. I recommend to write down the issueing cities from each region on a piece of paper... otherwise, you might lose quite some time checking every time. I have played this for 5 hours so far, in two sessions, and I notice that it really can eat away at your ability to concentrate, so I think this is best played casually... do like half an hour at a time so you don't burn yourself out.I really like the theme, as it DOES make you think a bit about how unfair the system in that country is, and you have to make some harsh decisions. There even are a few puzzles in there in the story-mode. Kudos to the developer... this is a fun little game, and to me, the old school graphics don't matter at all, as the core of the game is very well thought out, and it's fun!

You must do your job correctly, or be penalized. You need to take care of yourf amily by providing food, heat, and medicine if needed. The immigrants are quirky and often times fun to see. You must test your morality and your obedience. Overall, Papers, Please is amoung my Top 10 Favourite Games List.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
Short ReviewNarrative: Focuses on role-playingGameplay: Time Rush "Match the Picture" Point-and-ClickScore: 8/10Recommended: YesRecommended buying point: Any discount of 50% or aboveRecommended for: People who don't care about a game's length and more focused on the intensity of an experience it can giveDetailed ReviewThe NarrativeStory:You are the husband to a family of five, including you. You have been selected to work as an immigration officer in the border of the country. Basically, you are the paperwork inspector of the eastern side of the infamous Checkpoint Charlie[en.wikipedia.org].And that's it. You get a few snips of the immigrants' lives and story, and there is indeed a "larger" storyline that somewhat follows the historical Checkpoint Charlie, but the core focus of the story is you and your decisions. You have the greatest agency in the entire game: You get to decide the fate of all sorts of people and even that of the country itself! All through a bunch of bureacracy decisions. Of course, you need to remember that your decisions, ill-informed as it can be, also decides the fate of you and your family too. Rather than direct storytelling, the game puts a strong focus on storytelling through role-play.If there is one weakness with the story, however, is that some of the puzzles can be hard that it will lead you into searching for guides to solve them (an adventure game trademark, really) which would really break immersion in the game and story. The moment you stop making on-the-spot from-the-heart decisions with the scant information available and think of getting a certain achievement or ending, at that moment the game really lose its grip on you.Character:There isn't much of a characterization in here. As a character, the main character is 100% defined by your actions. You have a family, but they don't show up in the game - they barely even do anything other than being a bunch of mouth for you to keep warm, feed, and stay healthy - keep the alive as having all of them killed nets you a gameover. Some of the immigrants shows a certain characterization, but they are basically stranger which you only see for a few moments - as they are to you both in-character and meta-wise. The closest you have to legitimate characters are your co-workers.Most of the characters are just blank canvas for you to paint one - one person might think of one character as a jerk the other might think that he's not really a jerk. The focus in this game is in the role-play, there is little characterization so you fill in the blanks with what you think of them. Provided that you play this game completely honestly (which I recommend you doing until you reach Day 32/end-game once) then it can say a lot of interesting things about you. Apparently, I'm someone who can bend some rules and go against some moral and ethic codes so long as it isn't too big or if I need it. It is a rather interesting experience, and what makes this game really strong.The GameplayMechanics:The core mechanics of the game is basically similar to "Find what's different with the pictures" type of games. And easy comparison would be the Ace Attorney series of game, except this one is much more minimalistic in its storytelling, more focused in the 'courtroom' session, and less absurd or "anime-ish" but more grounded in reality.You are presented with a bunch of documents, you need to find what's wrong with it, and match it with the rules or the other data that acts as a reference for how they are wrong. You then need to find if the discrepancies were simply outdated data or if the documents really are invalid. If it was all cleared and there's nothing wrong with the document, you approve their visa, and if it's not, you can either deny them or detain them (the latter gives a small bonus). At the end of the day, you can choose if you want to feed your family and keep them warm or not, as well as whether or not to give them medicine if they are sick. You can upgrade the booth for some shortcut commands and you can move to a more expensive appartment at certain days (which does nothing except for getting one achievement). Other than the rents and fines, the bills are opt-out while the upgrades are opt-in.The game started rather difficult as there is a lack of tutorial - which admittedly does fit the image of the fictional country in that they demand nothing but the best from their workers. The game asks you to be constantly vigil and have a good memory about the rules. If you do not, then you might miss something that makes you get a warning from your superior or alternatively takes too long a time inspecting one immigrant meaning less immigrant processed and thus less money for you and your family. In a way, the core gameplay revolves around weighting your choices. Whether to rush the inspection out or to take your time, whether to be merciless or be nice, whether to accept bribes or not. The game focuses on these small moments and what it says about you. The gameplay mechanics are really just a vehicle for the role-playing part of the game, which is the main meat of the game.Overall, it's not really fun - and I'm sure it's not intended to be fun or at least not in the traditional way of fun - but it's good at what it's trying to do and it didn't overstay its welcome (you can finish this game in a single weekend, provided that you are good at it and know what you are doing). Although it is very annoying that many of the achievements are hidden and can be very hard to find unless you search a guide or the wiki (which as I said, can really break immersion in the game).Optimization:I was honestly surprised and floored by how light this game is. I would have thought that it would take a few hundreds megabyte, but then I saw that it only took about 50MB when I was downloading the game! And I have a rather old computer and to my surprise, it ran smoothly despite how I was opening a bunch of Chrome tabs and Notepad++ (with five open documents in it). My guess is that this is because of the very traditional art-style and how a lot of its contents are procedurally generated except for some few scripted encounters and dialogues in the game.The AestheticsGraphics:The graphics is very traditional - it wouldn't be out-of-place in the NES console. In terms of fidelity, it's pretty high in fidelity in spite of its look, and it could clearly show everything that is needed. The art style was rather drab, but it fits the tone and theme of the game, as well as that of the setting. If there is one thing I have to criticize out of the graphic is that the in-game photo and the game's sprite can often looks rather different, leading to some confused moments. Not much to say other than that - it does its job and that's that.Sound:There isn't much to say about the sound department. It has about two or so music and about a dozen or so of SFX, and that they do the jobs they needed to do. The music sets the mood pretty nicely but is otherwise not notable, especially since during the main segment of the game they do not have any music at all (the music are only on the main menu and ending, I believe). The sound effects were okay - very minimalistic but nothing out of place.]Final Verdict:8/10 - Overall, this is a very good game not in the gameplay but because of how immersive and bleak in can be. Is it worth your money? Well, if you want a lot of milestone from your games, then I'd say Maybe with capital M, but if you are searching for unique and interesting experiences, however, then I would definitely recommend this game. If it has a discount of 50%, then I strongly recommend buying this game.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2014
												At first, I was skeptical of Papers, Please, and felt a little silly explaining it to friends. I was pleasantly surprised how ever at what a wonderful and immersive concept it turned out to be. Yes, you are checking papers at a Border Checkpoint. However, you soon come to find there is more to it than the mundane stamping of passports. As days go by, terrorists attacks occur and it is clear that a more strict border regulation is needed. So, mostly each day, a new rule is implemented that you must adhere to. But then, then there are the people. Jorji... Ah, I'll let you experience this gem for yourselves. There are choices you have to make though. You must make these more decisions based on what YOU think... Will you let the wife pass with her husband even though she doesn't have proper papers? Over all, this is definitely worth the price and I would pay for it if it were more.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												Unbelievably grim, sad, depressing, almost frustrating game. The world you live in has real stories, your decisions will have irreversible consequences, not only to the people you decide upon, but your own consience. Should you take care of your sister's daughter after your sister death, when your own child have no food for 3 days now? Should you let a wife of a just passed-through traveller, to enter when her papers are not correct, knowing that any penalty can cause you to have no money to pay for heat and your own wife is sick at home? Even your desk does not have enough space to put on all the papers that you need to check...A magnficent game, one of the few games that can really TEACH something to you and your kids, how real life can be sometimes, and at the same time, enjoyable with interesting twists in the storyline that makes every decision you make count until the end. It is so amazing that this simple but well-polished game was developed by a single indie developer.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
Not all games should be about fun! --- Pros --- Good storytelling Art style and music Will make you feel the feels The puzzle aspect of the game keeps changing/adding rules --- Cons --- Slow Boring Clumsy interface (this are not actually cons read below for further explanation)You play the role af an Inspector on a border checkpoint and your job is to put stamps on passports... You gain little to no money from your job and have to provide for your family.... You will see many people wanting to cross borders in hopes of getting a better life but you find a discrepancy on their documents and you reject their entry... because its your job!For this facts some might say "Papers, Please" is a slow, boring game with clumsy interface... and i will not argue with that...That is its purpose! And by doing this it makes it the most humane game i ever played! Your character is as miserable as the people trying to cross the border! From doing a monotonous and meticulous job to having to toss/move papers around, everything makes it belivable and brings you in to the reality of their dystopia!I found myself laughing, saddened, puzzled and even mad while playing the game. What more can you ask of a game?Mandatory: GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												Papers, please is a unique and interesting game, you're basically a one man border control and trust me, it gets more interesting...Just looking at someone's face and seeing if it matches the passport photo isn't all of it, a lot of minor detail is included so that you have to pay attention carefully such as expiry date on the passport and region they are from etc. Don't worry, you get a warnings if you get it wrong but any more than 2 mistakes and you get fined.As you progress through the story, it's gets more challenging and there is more specific requirements thrown at you such as workers have to present a valid work permit and certain documents are needed.When you finish work, you get your pay and you have to feed your family, pay for heating and if your family is ill; medicine.The worst part is to make wise decisions, such as sacrificing heating for your sons medicine, if you don't pay for the medicine, your family member might die and thats pretty depressing since your salary is quite low.Although it might sound boring, there is an actual storyline to it, some events happen and your choice of actions might change the story a bit. You'll be glad that everyone you meet are different.Also, you can get some grumpy people who can♥♥♥♥♥♥you off or you can get people who are desperate to migrate because of war and they beg you to let them in even though they don't have a passport. Decision making is pretty heavy in this game.Overall, its interesting and fun game. I recommend it to those who have some time to kill and those who want pursue a border control career ;)

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												Papers, Please is a repetitive but challenging indie game where you act as a border control passport inspector. The goal of the game is to let the qualified people pass and reject the inqualified people. Every day there is a new set of rules or addition to the rules making each day still challenging and fun. The game is challenging at first to learn of the different conditions and what each is (such as the passport nations). However later on it becomes more of a "spot the error" kind of game. If you get 2 wrong, you will not be penalized, but if you get 3 wrong, you will start to lose money. At the end of every day you can devote your money to different things such as heat and food. However, if you chose not to devote money to those for long enough, bad things will happen to your family which is dependent on the money. If you go into the negatives after a day, you get arrested and it is game over.Overall pretty fun game and has a fitting soundtrack that plays when the game gets to certain points.Rating: 8.6/10

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												Papers, please is a unique and interesting game, you're basically a one man border control and trust me, it gets more interesting...Just looking at someone's face and seeing if it matches the passport photo isn't all of it, a lot of minor detail is included so that you have to pay attention carefully such as expiry date on the passport and region they are from etc. Don't worry, you get a warnings if you get it wrong but any more than 2 mistakes and you get fined.As you progress through the story, it's gets more challenging and there is more specific requirements thrown at you such as workers have to present a valid work permit and certain documents are needed.When you finish work, you get your pay and you have to feed your family, pay for heating and if your family is ill; medicine.The worst part is to make wise decisions, such as sacrificing heating for your sons medicine, if you don't pay for the medicine, your family member might die and thats pretty depressing since your salary is quite low.Although it might sound boring, there is an actual storyline to it, some events happen and your choice of actions might change the story a bit. You'll be glad that everyone you meet are different.Also, you can get some grumpy people who can♥♥♥♥♥♥you off or you can get people who are desperate to migrate because of war and they beg you to let them in even though they don't have a passport. Decision making is pretty heavy in this game.Overall, its interesting and fun game. I recommend it to those who have some time to kill and those who want pursue a border control career ;)

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												Unbelievably grim, sad, depressing, almost frustrating game. The world you live in has real stories, your decisions will have irreversible consequences, not only to the people you decide upon, but your own consience. Should you take care of your sister's daughter after your sister death, when your own child have no food for 3 days now? Should you let a wife of a just passed-through traveller, to enter when her papers are not correct, knowing that any penalty can cause you to have no money to pay for heat and your own wife is sick at home? Even your desk does not have enough space to put on all the papers that you need to check...A magnficent game, one of the few games that can really TEACH something to you and your kids, how real life can be sometimes, and at the same time, enjoyable with interesting twists in the storyline that makes every decision you make count until the end. It is so amazing that this simple but well-polished game was developed by a single indie developer.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												Papers, Please is a very strange and difficult to rate game. You are an immigration officer, charged with determining who to let into the fictional Eastern European communist country of Arstotzka. Even the genre of the game is rather hard to pin down; ultimately, the game boils down to trying to find inconsistencies in the papers, making it a puzzle game of sorts, but it somehow lends checking people’s paperwork an air of great gravity and tension, even if the actual activity itself is rather boring.I don’t know if you can really say that Papers, Please is a fun game; there is a great feeling of tension throughout, and yet also of monotony. Somehow, you feel obligated to keep your faceless family members alive; somehow, you feel like the question of a bribe is a real one that has real weight; somehow, you feel like what you’re doing is important. And yet, ultimately, you’re just checking paperwork and determining whether or not to let people through based on the paperwork and your own feelings about the situation.It is definitely an engaging experience, but I'm not sure if I can really say that I had fun playing it, apart from the interactions with Jorji and the tasks I did for EZIC. But I still played all the way through without putting it down.

												"Why not to take a trip to pass-dystopian 80s, and see all the might of Eastern Europe autocracys? Let's face together those lousy travellers and immigrants, as they wish to entry trough our strict borders. Get your documents ready, citizens! Check your passports, inhabitants! Make sure you have proper entry permits, foreigners! Or should we perhamps support our local conspiracy theoretics and shoot some arrogant ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, before they cross the line? We might also need to accept some of those bribe offers we're encountering to feed our starving families. Oh boy, my dear son's birthday is tomorrow, need to get a gift for him! But then we won't be able to buy any essential food or medicines tomorrow..." The atmosphere of this game is over the edge. All of your acts have consequences, everything is connected and nothing is guaranteened. After all, this might be one of the best indie-releases in the short run. Oh, and one more thing, before entering. "Papers, please?"

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
Not all games should be about fun! --- Pros --- Good storytelling Art style and music Will make you feel the feels The puzzle aspect of the game keeps changing/adding rules --- Cons --- Slow Boring Clumsy interface (this are not actually cons read below for further explanation)You play the role af an Inspector on a border checkpoint and your job is to put stamps on passports... You gain little to no money from your job and have to provide for your family.... You will see many people wanting to cross borders in hopes of getting a better life but you find a discrepancy on their documents and you reject their entry... because its your job!For this facts some might say "Papers, Please" is a slow, boring game with clumsy interface... and i will not argue with that...That is its purpose! And by doing this it makes it the most humane game i ever played! Your character is as miserable as the people trying to cross the border! From doing a monotonous and meticulous job to having to toss/move papers around, everything makes it belivable and brings you in to the reality of their dystopia!I found myself laughing, saddened, puzzled and even mad while playing the game. What more can you ask of a game?Mandatory: GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												While the first glimpse says to a store-wanderer ''boring, boring, boring'', this idea is completely false. Papers, Please is the complete opposite of boring.Taking place in a fictional semi-corrupt semi-just-want-MIA-members-kept-in-place country named Arstotzka, you play as a border control agent, accepting or denying job-seekers, immigrants and criminals. While this game's first few hours/minutes (depending on how quick your fingers are and how long it takes to strain them dragging documents around your messy desk) are quite dull, the people I saw in just that little amount of gameplay made me rage, laugh and stare. This is a brilliant attribute as it jolts the brain and your emotions to a flying start. Time to time the game gets harder and more time-consuming, but still follows the same laugh-rage experience. It also displays attributes of a shooter - you will sometimes see a terrorist attack and have the power to stop one at your protagonist's twiddling fingers. It also gives you opinions and puzzles (including the bomb some idiot thought would kill off an inspector and all the guards surrounding him), like managing your expenses and doing whatever it takes to not be arrested for giving a single document to the police. While this isn't too frequent it still makes you happy there's a change in the game and you have some freedom. Graphics-wise the game is pixellated, but looks lovely at the same time. This style fits the time the game was set, as I just thought, considering it is set in the 80s, a time when 8-bits were first introduced. It also displays musical talent, and the theme makes me want to go on a march in synchronization with it. So, overall, I'd say Papers, Please, from such a simple idea, turns out to be one of my favourite games of all time, and I congratulate Dukope for making such a brilliant game. 10/10. Glory to Arstotzka.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
Papers, Please manages to make what would seem like a midless task mean lots to the player, all while presenting new challenges and thrills throughout the game and managing to be terrifyingly immersive. This is the only game where poor controls can be described as intentional, and they are, to make the grinding task of passport-stamping intentionally tedious and frustrating. Even as a humble worker, you feel powerful as you stamp the papers of endless npcs, some of which contribute to the story. While it won't appeal to those gamers who want nothing but the finest gameplay, the aesthetic, story, message and overall tone of Papers, Please draws many to enjoy it. In fact, the strenuous task of paperwork shuffling can actually become fun and addicting to perfectionists like myself.While short, there are 20 endings in the game, 3 of which are considered "good". Obtaining my desired good ending is one of the most rewarding thigs I've experienced from a game.10 dollars is a bit of a stretch for those who don't know what they're getting from this game, but I would reccomend it to absolutely anyone on sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												This is a game that stuck with me and told a grim yet realistic story. While the graphics aren't spectacular and it's not the high intense gameplay you can get from other games, this is a game that took a mundane job and made it into a political commentary. I was skeptical initially thinking that a paper pushing game would be easy and I'd get bored of it. In reality, it was the opposite. The game's difficulty progressed with the story line, or in other words, the levels of bureaucracy and trying not to get too many citations. It gets harder when you have to deal with terrorists and providing for your family. The historical backdrop of East and West Germany (ofc in fictional terms) made it even more realistic and moving. This game  impacted me and it is a true masterpiece.Of course, it is not flawless, at times it can feel a bit repetitive and while you can have many endings (20 in fact), it's hard to replay it immediately (better wait a few months to try it again). In short, if you'd like a break from an FPS and try to be an immigration inspector then this game is for you.Glory to Arstotzka.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Papers, Please is one of the most innovating and impressive games from this year. Being a sort of point-and-click game, Papers, Please excels in the way it uses it.You take the role of an Arstotzkan border controller who regulates the border checkpoint in Grestin, Arstotzka.You must earn money by doing your job accordingly and with as few errors as possible in order to feed and protect your family, as well as keeping them healthy and living under a roof.The game focuses on the basic mechanics of point-and-click, but uses this mechanic in a very different way by allowing the player to check entrees' passports as they attempt to enter the country of Arstotzka. Your duty, as border controll, is to make sure that only people with valid documents enter the country.If you make any errors, small amounts of your salary will be held back, and you may even allow in a terrorist if the person that you allowed entrance carried a bomb and you forgot to x-ray them because they had expired documents, for example.The game has a very simple art direction, as well as a very simple sound design. Lucas Pope, the creator of the game, really nailed it with Papers, Please, as he created something inspiring, entertaining, and very different.Papers, Please is one of its kind, and is one of those rare indie games that you should defnitely try out.The only complaint I have is that the main story is too short, but even so, the game has a freemode and so you can continue to play on without focusing on the main story, even though the main story is crafted in a specific way and has its own events, the freemode is very fun too.No more needs to be said.Glory to Arstotzka.
